About/Colophon.title: Colophon
About/Colophon.content:
This site is build with Quartz v4, which is a static-site generator that transforms a folder of Markdown files into a website.
It’s designed to work well with Obsidian’s features, and that is what I use to write my content. I’m not that deep in the Obsidian ecosystem, and I don’t really use any advanced features, but everything about it, especially PC/Mobile cross-functionality, is pretty good.
Because I access my Obsidian Vault on both desktop and mobile, the vault is saved in a weird location in my iCloud drive:
~/Library/Mobile Documents/iCloud~md~obsidian/Documents/Obsidian/

When building this site with Quartz, I have a script that batch-copies the files from my Obsidian vault into the Quartz folder, which it then uses to generate the site. The generated site is pushed to Github, where I have an Action setup to copy the contents of the content/ folder to my VPS.
I’ve always felt that it’s unwieldy to install static-site generators on the VPS, so I prefer to do the generation on my local machine and just copy over the outputted files.

About/Site-todo.title: Site todo
About/Site-todo.content:
In addition to using this site as a general wiki for my thoughts, I’m eyeing the possibility of migrating my entire blog to this format. I Currently make my site with Jekyll (a great product!) but I have a lot of customization living in each post’s frontmatter, and while I do have a variety of convenience scripts set up, I kind of need to be sitting at my desktop machine in order to create and publish posts.
With Quartz, I just add a new file somewhere, slap on a few words, and it’s already a part of my website. I want to see if there is a way to stay within this dead-simple workflow, and somehow recreate the functionality of my current site.

Coding/direnv.title: direnv
Coding/direnv.content:
direnv lets you define environment variables to be loaded only within certain directories. It’s a great way to save secret variables that are project-specific, without cluttering your global shell config.
Installation
brew install direnv
echo 'eval "$(direnv hook zsh)"' >> ~/.zshrc

Usage
echo 'export SECRET_TOKEN="super-secret"' > .envrc
echo 'export API_KEY="12345"' >> .envrc
direnv allow

Whenever you cd into this folder, the environment variables will load.
Don’t commit the secrets!
Add to .gitignore:
.envrc

games/Chaos-Zero-Nightmare/Duplicating-c.title: Duplicating cards effectively
games/Chaos-Zero-Nightmare/Duplicating-c.content:
A lot of characters benefit greatly from having a key card duplicated as many times as possible. One time is good, but two times (or even more?) is fantastic.
Each Copy Card event in Chaos randomly selects 3 cards, of which you choose 1 to copy. If you want your target card to appear as one of the choices, one strategy is to remove as many alternatives as possible.
Instead of removing basic cards right away, instead remove other characters’ unique cards. By sacrificing their deck’s strength, you can build one deck to be especially strong.
Unique cards
Some characters have cards with the Unique attribute, which means they can’t be copied. Some cards gain Unique from Epiphanies. Since Unique cards will not be chosen as Copy targets, you don’t need to remove them in preparation for Copy events.
Pairing characters with these cards will make it a little bit easier to copy the card you are targeting.

games/Chaos-Zero-Nightmare/micro/2025120.content:
Chizuru is interesting, but doesn’t really add anything new to my lineup since Mei-Lin is already strong single-target.
Obvious synergy is with Rin and Tressa, and I don’t have either of them built. Shame that Renoa’s bullet discard doesn’t trigger Will-o-wisp.
A strong multi-target attacker is probably what I need, and that makes me wonder if I should have just pulled Yuki. But using her in her showcase was kind of underwhelming and I’m not sold on the character design either.
So I think I need to just resist the FOMO and wait for someone I can really get behind.
